form.longName: PhenX PX520104 - Acutesubj Resp Tosubst Current Spec Tobacco
form.preferredDefinition: The Cigarette Evaluation Questionnaire (CEQ) assesses the degree to which subjects experience the reinforcing effects of smoking. It is a self-administered questionnaire that contains 11 items covering both the reinforcing and the adverse effects of smoking, asking subjects to rate the extent to which recently smoked cigarettes were satisfying, tasted good, made them dizzy, calmed them down, helped them concentrate, made them feel more awake, reduced appetite, made them nauseous, decreased irritability, produced enjoyable sensations in the throat and chest, and immediately reduced craving for cigarettes. The modified Cigarette Evaluation Questionnaire (mCEQ) contains an extra item on enjoying smoking in addition to the 11 original items. The items are rated on a seven-point scale ranging from 1 for "Not at all" to 7 for "Extremely."

module.longName: Acute Subjective Response to Substances - Current - Specific - Tobacco
module.preferredDefinition: Acute Subjective Response to Substances - Current - Specific - Tobacco

question.questionText: 1. Was smoking satisfying? (was_smoking_satisfying)
2. Did cigarettes taste good? (did_cigarettes_taste_good)
3. Did you enjoy the sensations in your throat and chest? (enjoy_the_sensations)
4. Did smoking calm you down? (smoking_calm_you_down)
5. Did smoking make you feel more awake? (smoking_make_you_more_awake)
6. Did smoking make you feel less irritable? (make_you_less_irritable)
7. Did smoking help you concentrate? (smoking_help_you_concentrate)
8. Did smoking reduce your hunger for food? (reduce_your_hunger)
9. Did smoking make you dizzy? (smoking_make_you_dizzy)
10. Did smoking make you nauseous? (smoking_make_you_nauseous)
11. Did smoking immediately relieve your craving for a cigarette? (smoking_relieve_your_craving)
12. Did you enjoy smoking? (did_you_enjoy_smoking)

Scoring Procedure and Interpretation The modified Cigarette Evaluation Questionnaire (mCEQ) uses three multiitem subscales and two single items: "Smoking Satisfaction" (items 1, 2, and 12) "Psychological Reward" (items 4 through 8) "Aversion" (items 9 and 10) "Enjoyment of Respiratory Tract Sensations" (item 3) and "Craving Reduction" (item 11). Scores for each subscale are calculated as the mean of the individual item responses or the single item. Higher scores indicate greater intensity on that scale. *1= not at all *2= very little *3= a little *4= moderately *5= a lot *6= quite a lot *7= extremely (scoring_5201044)

protocol.longName: Acute Subjective Response to Substances - Current - Specific - Tobacco
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Cigarette Evaluation Questionnaire (CEQ) assesses the degree to which subjects experience the reinforcing effects of smoking. It is a self-administered questionnaire that contains 11 items covering both the reinforcing and the adverse effects of smoking, asking subjects to rate the extent to which recently smoked cigarettes were satisfying, tasted good, made them dizzy, calmed them down, helped them concentrate, made them feel more awake, reduced appetite, made them nauseous, decreased irritability, produced enjoyable sensations in the throat and chest, and immediately reduced craving for cigarettes. The modified Cigarette Evaluation Questionnaire (mCEQ) contains an extra item on enjoying smoking in addition to the 11 original items. The items are rated on a seven-point scale ranging from 1 for "Not at all" to 7 for "Extremely."

form.longName: PhenX PX520201 - Acute Subj Responses To Substretrospectivetobacco
form.preferredDefinition: This instrument uses a set of self-administered questions to assess early response to tobacco smoking, and it may also be used for marijuana smoking. Seven items inquire about pleasant and unpleasant experiences and ask respondents if they encountered various effects while smoking a tobacco cigarette for the first time. Pleasurable and unpleasant sensations are rated on a scale ranging from 1 for "none" to 4 for "intense." Pleasurable rush or buzz, relaxation, nausea, cough, and dizziness are checked "yes" or "no," depending on the respondent's experience.

headerInstruction.text: Please rate the extent to which these words describe your feelings the very first time you smoked a cigarette.

module.longName: Acute Subjective Responses to Substances - Retrospective - Tobacco
module.preferredDefinition: Acute Subjective Responses to Substances - Retrospective - Tobacco

question.questionText: While smoking your very first cigarette, did you have pleasurable sensations? (first_cigarette_pleasurable_sensations)
While smoking your very first cigarette, did you have unpleasant sensations? (first_cigarette_unpleasant_sensations)
Please answer yes or no to the following questions about the very first cigarette you smoked (info_520201)
While smoking your very first cigarette, did you have a pleasurable buzz or rush? (first_cigarette_buzz_or_rush)
While smoking your very first cigarette, did you feel relaxed? (first_cigarette_feel_relaxed)
While smoking your very first cigarette, did you feel dizzy? (first_cigarette_feel_dizzy)
While smoking your very first cigarette, did you have nausea? (first_cigarette_nausea)
While smoking your very first cigarette, did you cough? (first_cigarette_cough)
Were you alone the first time you experimented with cigarettes? (first_cigarette_alone)

protocol.longName: Acute Subjective Responses to Substances - Retrospective - Tobacco
protocol.preferredDefinition: This instrument uses a set of self-administered questions to assess early response to tobacco smoking, and it may also be used for marijuana smoking. Seven items inquire about pleasant and unpleasant experiences and ask respondents if they encountered various effects while smoking a tobacco cigarette for the first time. Pleasurable and unpleasant sensations are rated on a scale ranging from 1 for "none" to 4 for "intense." Pleasurable rush or buzz, relaxation, nausea, cough, and dizziness are checked "yes" or "no," depending on the respondent's experience.

form.longName: PhenX PX520202 - Acute Subj Responses To Substretrospectivealcohol
form.preferredDefinition: The Self-Rating of the Effects of Alcohol (SRE) is a self-administered questionnaire that asks the respondent to think back about their drinking (approximately his/her first five times of drinking) and to list the number of standard drinks (10–12 g of ethanol) required to experience the effects of alcohol, which include feelings of intoxication, slurred speech, feeling unsteady or developing a stumbling gait, and unwanted falling asleep. Respondents are instructed to list only the alcohol effects they actually experienced during their earliest drinking time frame.

module.longName: Acute Subjective Responses to Substances - Retrospective - Alcohol
module.preferredDefinition: Acute Subjective Responses to Substances - Retrospective - Alcohol

question.questionText: How many drinks did it take for you to begin to feel different? (where you could feel an effect): First 5 times you ever drank (number_drinks_feel_different_first)
How many drinks did it take for you to begin to feel different? (where you could feel an effect): Recent 3 months drinking once a month (number_drinks_feel_different_recent)
How many drinks did it take for you to begin to feel different? (where you could feel an effect): Period of heaviest drinking (number_drinks_feel_different_heaviest)
How many drinks did it take for you to feel a bit dizzy or to begin to slur your speech? First 5 times you ever drank (number_drinks_feel_dizzy_first)
How many drinks did it take for you to feel a bit dizzy or to begin to slur your speech? Recent 3 months drinking once a month (number_drinks_feel_dizzy_recent)
How many drinks did it take for you to feel a bit dizzy or to begin to slur your speech? Period of heaviest drinking (number_drinks_feel_dizzy_heaviest)
How many drinks did it take you to begin stumbling, or walking in an uncoordinated manner? First 5 times you ever drank (number_drinks_stumbling_first)
How many drinks did it take you to begin stumbling, or walking in an uncoordinated manner? Recent 3 months drinking once a month (number_drinks_stumbling_recent)
How many drinks did it take you to begin stumbling, or walking in an uncoordinated manner? Period of heaviest drinking (number_drinks_stumbling_heaviest)
How many drinks did it take you to pass out, or fall asleep when you did not want to? First 5 times you ever drank (number_drinks_pass_out_first)
How many drinks did it take you to pass out, or fall asleep when you did not want to? Recent 3 months drinking once a month (number_drinks_pass_out_recent)
How many drinks did it take you to pass out, or fall asleep when you did not want to? Period of heaviest drinking (number_drinks_pass_out_heaviest)

protocol.longName: Acute Subjective Responses to Substances - Retrospective - Alcohol
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Self-Rating of the Effects of Alcohol (SRE) is a self-administered questionnaire that asks the respondent to think back about their drinking (approximately his/her first five times of drinking) and to list the number of standard drinks (10–12 g of ethanol) required to experience the effects of alcohol, which include feelings of intoxication, slurred speech, feeling unsteady or developing a stumbling gait, and unwanted falling asleep. Respondents are instructed to list only the alcohol effects they actually experienced during their earliest drinking time frame.

form.longName: PhenX PX520301 - Selfreported Craving Specific Alcohol
form.preferredDefinition: The Alcohol Urge Questionnaire (AUQ) consists of eight statements about the respondent's feelings and thoughts about drinking as they are completing the questionnaire (i.e., right now). Drinking refers to various types of alcohol, including beer, wine and liquor. The respondent is asked to respond to each statement about alcohol craving via a 7-item Likert scale ranging from "strongly disagree" to "strongly agree."

headerInstruction.text: Listed below are questions that ask about your feelings about drinking. The words "drinking" and "have a drink" refer to having a drink containing alcohol such as beer, wine, or liquor. Please indicate how much you agree or disagree with each ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. All I want to do now is have a drink. (all_want_is_drink)
2. I do not need to have a drink now. (do_not_need_drink)
3. It would be difficult to turn down a drink this minute. (difficult_to_turn_downdrink)
4. Having a drink now would make things seem just perfect. (having_a_drink_perfect)
5. I want a drink so bad I can almost taste it. (want_drink_almost_taste)
6. Nothing would be better than having a drink right now. (nothing_better_than_drink)
7. If I had the chance to have a drink, I don't think I would drink it. (chance_to_drink_would_not)
8. I crave a drink right now. (crave_a_drink)

Scoring Procedure and Interpretation Each item is scored on a 1 to 7 scale (Strongly Disagree = 1 and Strongly Agree = 7). Items 2 and 7 are reverse scored. A total score is computed by averaging the item scores. Higher scores reflect greater craving (scoring_520301)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Alcohol Urge Questionnaire (AUQ) consists of eight statements about the respondent's feelings and thoughts about drinking as they are completing the questionnaire (i.e., right now). Drinking refers to various types of alcohol, including beer, wine and liquor. The respondent is asked to respond to each statement about alcohol craving via a 7-item Likert scale ranging from "strongly disagree" to "strongly agree."

form.longName: PhenX PX520302 - Selfreported Craving Specific Cocaine
form.preferredDefinition: The Cocaine Craving Questionnaire–Brief (CCQ–Brief) consists of 10 statements about the respondent's feelings and thoughts about using cocaine as her or she is completing the questionnaire (i.e., right now). This instrument allows investigators to obtain a reflection of the respondent's general cocaine craving.

headerInstruction.text: Indicate how strongly you agree or disagree with each of the following statements by selecting a number between 1 (STRONGLY DISAGREE) and 7 (STRONGLY AGREE). The closer your selection to one end or the other indicates the strength of your agre..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. I want cocaine so bad I can almost taste it. (want_cocaine_almost_taste)
2. I have an urge for cocaine. (urge_for_cocaine)
3. I am going to use cocaine as soon as possible. (use_cocaine_soon_as_possible)
4. I think that I could resist using "coke" now. (could_resist_using_coke)
5. I crave "coke" right now. (crave_coke)
6. All I want to use now is cocaine. (want_to_use_cocaine)
7. I have no desire for cocaine right now. (no_desire_for_cocaine)
8. Using cocaine now would make things seem just perfect. (cocaine_make_things_perfect)
9. I will use cocaine as soon as I get the chance. (use_cocaine_soon)
10. Nothing would be better than using "coke" right now. (nothing_better_than_coke_now)

Scoring Procedure and Interpretation :Each item is scored on a scale ranging from 1 for "Strongly Disagree" to 7 for "Strongly Agree." The scores from items 13, 5, 6, and 810 are used as the raw scores. Items 4 and 7 should be reversescored (raw score = 8 minus reversekeyed item score) (Heinz et al., 2006). A total score is obtained by averaging all items (Sussner et al., 2006) (scoring_510302)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Cocaine Craving Questionnaire–Brief (CCQ–Brief) consists of 10 statements about the respondent's feelings and thoughts about using cocaine as her or she is completing the questionnaire (i.e., right now). This instrument allows investigators to obtain a reflection of the respondent's general cocaine craving.
